results.headline: Remembering When Dad Came Out

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beginners

results.summary_short: Christopher Plummer and Ewan McGregor star in “Beginners,” a wistful memory piece about a straight son and his dying gay father.

results.headline: Enhancing the Image of Feminist Art
results.display_title: ! Women Art Revolution: A Secret History

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of ! Women Art Revolution: A Secret History

results.summary_short: A documentary makes the case that the feminist art movement has been more influential than is generally acknowledged.

results.headline: Heaven, Texas and the Cosmic Whodunit

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Tree of Life

results.summary_short: “The Tree of Life,” directed by Terrence Malick, envisions the origin of the universe and ponders some of life’s deepest questions.

results.headline: Circular Firing Squad, Run by Young Radicals

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of United Red Army

results.summary_short: In “United Red Army” Koji Wakamatsu charts the rise and self-destruction of a Japanese extremist group.

results.headline: Blood-Drenched Whimsy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Are the Night

results.summary_short: “We Are the Night” is a horror movie involving a glam gang of female vampires.

results.headline: Thespian Dreams

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tied to a Chair

results.summary_short: “Tied to a Chair” is the story of a has-been director and a middle-aged housewife obsessed with reviving her youthful thespian dreams.

results.headline: The Siren Song of Groupthink

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wave!

results.summary_short: “The Wave,” based on a 1967 teaching experiment in California, transplants the action to modern-day Germany, where a classroom is turned into a groupthink dictatorship.

results.headline: Life on the Fringe

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Spork

results.summary_short: “Spork,” a sort-of musical comedy about a teenage outcast who is also a hermaphrodite, has echoes of “Hairspray.”

results.headline: Solving Puzzles to Help With the Riddle of Midlife

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Puzzle

results.summary_short: In the Argentine film “Puzzle,” the actress María Onetto plays a middle-class homemaker who stumbles onto a hobby that gives her life meaning.

results.headline: Among Lonelyhearts, a Meeting of Minds

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hello Lonesome

results.summary_short: Three separate stories explore human connections and the limbo of the lonely unattached.

results.headline: 3 Men and a Monkey-Baby

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hangover Part II

results.summary_short: Bradley Cooper, Zach Galifianakis and Ed Helms return as buds in trouble before a marriage in sequel to Todd Phillips’s hit.

results.headline: A Noble Panda Takes On a Nightmare Enemy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kung Fu Panda 2

results.summary_short: Po, the hero of “Kung Fu Panda 2,” works out his identity crisis and faces Shen, the villainous peacock who has conducted a campaign of genocide against pandas.

results.headline: Case of Romanian Realism: Regular Guy, With Wife and Girlfriend

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tuesday, After Christmas

results.summary_short: “Tuesday, After Christmas,” a Romanian film directed by Radu Muntean, tells the story of a married regular guy who is having an affair with his daughter’s dentist.

results.headline: The Old Ennui and the Lost Generation

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Midnight in Paris

results.summary_short: Woody Allen, with the help of Paris and the ghosts of its famous dead, has found a credible blend of whimsy and wisdom.

results.headline: Florent, the Restaurant and the Man, on Film
results.display_title: Florent: Queen of the Meat Market

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Florent: Queen of the Meat Market

results.summary_short: High rents and changing times claimed the all-night restaurant and neighborhood landmark.

results.headline: Whale Oil Explodes and Buccaneers Bellow
results.display_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides

results.summary_short: While this picture is called “On Stranger Tides,” it is by far the least strange of all the “Pirates” episodes so far.

results.headline: The Residents Go, the Music Stays

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lost Bohemia

results.summary_short: “Lost Bohemia,” Josef Astor’s documentary, chronicles the eviction of the last residents of Carnegie Hall Studios.

results.headline: A Solemn Homecoming

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cost of a Soul

results.summary_short: The drama “Cost of a Soul” follows two Iraq War veterans back home to Philadelphia and the families they left behind.

results.headline: A Romance Stalked by Hatred

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Children of God

results.summary_short: “Children of God” tells a story of a romance in Eleuthera and the homophobia it attracts.

results.headline: A Stream of Words, Painting a Picture

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Louder Than a Bomb

results.summary_short: The documentary “Louder Than a Bomb” follows four teams of teenagers as they prepare for a high school poetry slam in Chicago.
